hints_html:
In order for eAt to be unitary, we need \(\left(e^{At}\right)^{H} e^{At} = I.\)

Use the Maclaurin Expansion \(e^{x}= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{k}}{k!}\)
hints_latex:
In order for \emph{e\textsuperscript{At}} to be unitary, we need
$\left(e^{At}\right)^{H} e^{At} = I.$
hints_raw:
In order for ''e<sup>At</sup>'' to be unitary, we need <math>\left(e^{At}\right)^{H} e^{At} = I.</math>
Use the Maclaurin Expansion <math>e^{x}= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{k}}{k!}</math>
sols_html:
Calculating the Maclaurin expansion we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \left(e^{At}\right)^{H} = \left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(At)^{k}}{k!}\right)^{H} = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(A^{H}t)^{k}}{k!}=e^{\left(A^{H}\right)t}\end{aligned}\]

Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} \left(e^{At}\right)^{H} e^{At}=\left(e^{A^{H}t}\right)e^{At}=\left(e^{-At}\right)e^{At}=e^{0}=I.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Calculating the Maclaurin expansion we find that 

:<math>\left(e^{At}\right)^{H} = \left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(At)^{k}}{k!}\right)^{H} = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(A^{H}t)^{k}}{k!}=e^{\left(A^{H}\right)t}</math>

Thus,

:<math>\left(e^{At}\right)^{H} e^{At}=\left(e^{A^{H}t}\right)e^{At}=\left(e^{-At}\right)e^{At}=e^{0}=I.</math>
statement_html:
Let AH = -A be a skew-Hermitian complex matrix. Show that the matrix eAt is unitary.

Note: The superscript H denotes the Hermitian conjugate \((\mathbf{A}^H)_{ij} = \overline{\mathbf{A}_{ji}}\), which is often also called adjoint matrix or conjugate transpose and written as A* = AH.
statement_latex:
Let \emph{A\textsuperscript{H} = -A} be a skew-Hermitian complex matrix.
Show that the matrix \emph{e\textsuperscript{At}} is unitary.

\emph{Note:} The superscript \emph{H} denotes the
{Hermitian
conjugate} $(\mathbf{A}^H)_{ij} = \overline{\mathbf{A}_{ji}}$, which is
often also called \emph{adjoint matrix} or \emph{conjugate transpose}
and written as \emph{A\textsuperscript{*} = A\textsuperscript{H}}.
statement_raw:
Let ''A<sup>H</sup> = -A'' be a skew-Hermitian complex matrix. Show that the matrix ''e<sup>At</sup>'' is unitary.

''Note:'' The superscript ''H'' denotes the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjugate_transpose Hermitian conjugate] <math>(\mathbf{A}^H)_{ij} = \overline{\mathbf{A}_{ji}}</math>, which is often also called ''adjoint matrix'' or ''conjugate transpose'' and written as ''A<sup>*</sup> = A<sup>H</sup>''.
